author: Soggy-Prune
body:
MCD is a good dividend play, good yield and growth. V has a low yield but high growth. I own both. 

I own dividend stocks because it makes it easier to hold things like SHOP, AMZN, PAYC, NFLX, GOOGL, NVDA (negligible dividend but I’ll take it). The dividends pay my living expense and the non-payers just sit in my portfolio and get bigger. All my stocks have a job, though not the same exact function. 

Would I have been better off with a portfolio of 100% SHOP calls? YOLO FTW? That would have done even better than QQQ, VUG, MCD or V, right? Well yeah, but I want to preserve my wealth as well as grow it. I also want to preserve my sanity. I want to sleep well at night, most nights. If I doubled my  net worth tomorrow it would not have a dramatic effect on my life, but if I lost it all I’d be ruined. I’m too old for that shit. 

So it all depends on your goals and life circumstances too. If you’re young and in accumulation mode, go for capital gains. Dividends literally do not matter to you; total return is all. If you’re old and in withdrawal mode, dividends have a place (so do bonds). Chasing yield rarely ends well though.

author: firestormdude
body:
They have outperformed and kicked ass. I’m a paid subscriber and they’ve recommended the following since the beginning of the year and you would have made out like a bandit with these in your portfolio:

Activision

Zynga

Twilio

Amazon

Tesla

Fastly

ServiceNow

Nice

Mastercard

Shopify

Nvidia

The Trade Desk

Facebook

Apple

Okta

Crowd strike

Netflix

Appian

Match Group

Paycom Software

JD.com

PayPal

They get a few crap ones like Luckin Coffee but majority of their recommendations are gold. They focus on disruptive and growing tech you can buy and hold for 3-5 years. Heavy emphasis on the cloud.

Do your research but they’ve turned me onto a lot of good stocks I now own and crushed it by owning.

author: ixamnis
body:
RBC capitol just upgraded them yesterday from "Perform" to "Outperform." Recognia Technical analysis rates them "Strong" for both the short term and the long term.

S&P Global Capital Intelligence rates them as neither overvalued nor undervalued, giving them a score of 57/100, where 100 = very undervalued and 0 = very over valued.

Of the companies that do similar work, only Paycom seems to be rated a bit higher.

Looks like a solid company.

(Information taken from [Fidelity.com](https://Fidelity.com); I do not own shares in this company)

author: yura37
body: 100k qqq 10k tqqq  40k amzn 100k between ko, ibm, tan, pg, and smh 10k fro 20k ttd 10k docu 20k lulu 5k payc 5k ayx 30k gld or metal of choice. Stop losses ~5-10% on everything. I would wait for 10-15% drawdown before entry on individual equities since everything is super extended. That's if i had to do stocks. Currently I'm monitoring my trades every day so i would throw 200k in those same stocks, sell covered calls, and the other 150k would be options plays.

author: dreammanalishi
body:
PAYC

PCTY

ANET

RBBN

off the top of my head... those have been up and down enough to make me more money than some of the meme stocks but are along the same vein.

Generally, finding stocks related to meme stocks works best for me because by the time you see a news article or a post the market has already reacted.

Certain correlated tickers and even ETFs often experience a delayed reaction, making it easier to buy and sell it for a fraction of a percent a few hundred times in a couple of days.

author: spectral_fall
body:
This really helped me rebalance my portfolio. I'm going to remove KMI, DFS, RIO and add AMZN, VEEV, TTWO, JPM, SCHW (they're buying out Ameritrade), EGAN (risky but AI development is a good long-term tech-hold IMO), and FRTA. 

I'm still keeping both CVX and COP since I really like both companies and their levels of diversification. I may be light on healthcare but it's an improvement. 

27% Tech: AMZN(5%), MSFT (5%), NVDA (3%), INTC(3%), NOW (3%), PAYC (3%), TTWO (3%), EGAN (2%)

14% Finance: AXP(5%), JPM (5%), SCHW (4%)

14% Energy: COP (5%), CVX (5%), AES(4%) 

14% Airlines & Defense: LUV (5%), RTX (5%), GD (4%)

9% Consumer Discretionary: WMT (5%) TSCO (4%) 

7% healthcare: MCK (4%), VEEV (3%)

6% Industry & Mining: FRTA (3%), STLD (3%)

5% Utilities/Consumer Services: WM (5%)

author: AngelaQQ
body: The profitable pure-play SaaS companies are absolute cash flow beasts (Salesforce, Paycom etc.)

author: yura37
body:
I was investing in AYX before the crash, the company looks good and their 10-ks are more than acceptable for a growing tech company. They were in my top 3 tech investments with PAYC and TTD. very solid earnings growth and a subscription model that doesnt need much upkeep to make money down the line. 

AutoDesk and CAD are industry standards in lots of engineering, they are like the Adobe of designing. you take special classes and learn how to do your job with the tools given to you in cad. its very hard to switch over. I used to work as a pipeliner and fucking EVERYTHING is cad drawings. I hear the same from my engineer buddy that works in aerospace. Doesnt even matter if the software is good, their moat is legit. 

didnt see a tldr so i just read the end of your post.

author: AngelaQQ
body:
B2B SaaS companies are incredibly good businesses.

They're straight up cash generating, recurring revenue machines, and easy to get profitable in a hurry.

Companies like Paycom have been profitable for years already, and have been growing both top and bottom line at an incredible rate. Makes you wonder why anyone would want to make actual tangible stuff, when selling services via subscription is so lucrative.
